message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including persistent lower back pain, osteopenia, and multiple lytic lesions, suggest multiple myeloma as the most likely diagnosis. A bone marrow biopsy is the most definitive test for multiple myeloma. Peripheral blood smear is unlikely to reveal any abnormality in this case. Parathyroid hormone levels may be useful in diagnosing hyperparathyroidism, but the symptoms and laboratory results make multiple myeloma a more likely diagnosis. A skeletal survey is useful for evaluating bone density and detecting any fractures, but it is not the most definitive test for multiple myeloma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has multiple lytic lesions and diffuse osteopenia, which suggests multiple myeloma. To confirm the diagnosis, a bone marrow biopsy should be done. Peripheral blood smear and parathyroid hormone levels will not confirm this diagnosis. A skeletal survey can show lytic lesions but is not confirmatory.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient shows signs of multiple myeloma, which can cause lytic lesions in the bone and renal dysfunction. Parathyroid hormone and skeletal survey would not fully confirm the diagnosis, while a peripheral blood smear would not be useful in this case. A bone marrow biopsy is the most reliable method to diagnose multiple myeloma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and laboratory studies suggest multiple myeloma, a type of bone marrow cancer. The best way to confirm this diagnosis is to perform a bone marrow biopsy to assess the percentage of plasma cells in the bone marrow. A skeletal survey might be useful to identify the extent of bone lesions, but it is not the most specific test to confirm the diagnosis. Peripheral blood smear and parathyroid hormone levels are not helpful for diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory results suggest multiple myeloma, a cancer of plasma cells. Bone marrow biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis. The other options are not specific for multiple myeloma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including decreased urine output, bilateral pedal edema, and diffuse osteopenia with multiple lytic lesions, suggest a possible diagnosis of multiple myeloma. Bone marrow biopsy is the most definitive test to confirm the diagnosis, as it would show plasma cell infiltration. Peripheral blood smear can also show abnormal plasma cells, but is not as sensitive as a bone marrow biopsy. Parathyroid hormone levels and skeletal survey are not relevant to the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and lab results suggest multiple myeloma as a possible diagnosis. Bone marrow biopsy is the most reliable test to confirm this. A peripheral blood smear may show rouleaux formation, but is not diagnostic. Parathyroid hormone levels and skeletal survey are not relevant to the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the patient's symptoms, laboratory findings, and x-ray results, the most likely diagnosis is multiple myeloma, which is confirmed through a bone marrow biopsy. A peripheral blood smear may show abnormal cells, but it is not definitive for multiple myeloma. Parathyroid hormone levels may be elevated in patients with multiple myeloma, but it would not confirm the diagnosis. A skeletal survey may show lytic lesions, but it is not as definitive as a bone marrow biopsy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of lower back pain, lytic lesions, and elevated calcium levels suggest multiple myeloma. The best way to confirm this diagnosis is through a bone marrow biopsy. Peripheral blood smear is unlikely to show specific findings for multiple myeloma. Parathyroid hormone levels may be elevated in hyperparathyroidism but would not explain the other symptoms. A skeletal survey may show lytic lesions but would not provide a definitive diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory results suggest multiple myeloma, which leads to lytic bone lesions and osteopenia. Bone marrow biopsy is necessary to confirm the diagnosis. Peripheral blood smear is not helpful for diagnosing multiple myeloma. Parathyroid hormone levels can help diagnose hyperparathyroidism but is not relevant for this case. Skeletal survey can also help diagnose multiple myeloma, but is not the most definitive test.
